note.p: This letter was written to Seamus Fitzgerald (1896–1972). Fitzgerald, a Cork politician who channeled his patriotism into day to day efforts to establish Ireland as a modern nation. Fitzgerald joined the Irish Volunteers and Sinn Féin after Easter Week 1916, he was then arrested and sent to Frongoch, Wales, one of the seven places in which he was interned in subsequent years.

This is an emotive letter to Seamus from his mother Alice counselling him to keep his spirits up for fear "you will make me worse than what I am". She hopes his friends will be sent to the same place so they could be company for him. His father has not been told of Seamus' arrest "God is good and Blessed Mother you may be home before him yet".

div.p:
So your shifted
after all.
Now Jim What
ever you do I dont want
you to feel down hearted
Keep your spirit up & the
Great God in his mercy is
Great. We wont despair
yet. More mind cheer
up if you'll get downhearted
you will make me worse
than what I am. I dare
say you have seen Liel &Thom
by now. They will tell you all.

Tis strange your not getting
my letters. Mick Leahy has the same to say
about his mothers. I can't
understand it. Is
O'Brien with you.I hope
they are for they would
be company for you.
Now Lily will make
arrangements with some one
outside to visit you &
see to you & dont at all
fear him But everything
that possibly can be done
will be done for you love
I'm giving you great hope
& another thing if you are
kept there very long Bob
& myself & maybe Patrick
will go over to see you
for we are all dying to
see you. I haven't told
your father anything about
you up to the present
God is good & Blessed Mother
you may be home before
him yet. Poor Bob has
missed you terrible We
havent done a thing since
you left. You must have
felt in a terrible way
when you heard of this shift
again that's why I'm

warning you not to despair
don't take it to heart Jim
for mercy sake, that's
what I'm grieving for.
I will be dying for Liel &
Thom to come home to tell
me all about you. So I
will now conclude with
fondest Love from all
at home & again asking
you to cheer up & with
God's help you may be
with us sooner than what you
expect is this dearest.
